head.title: Epilogue.11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 1, 1796). The “Epilogue” was first performed as the finale for Turnbull’s benefit performance of the nautical drama Just in Time, for which he also wrote additional songs.

lg.l: All the world’s a stage—so says the Poet,22 Shakespeare, As you Like It (1623), II.vii.
And all our aims and all our actions shew it.
The noisy lawyer wrangling at the bar,
Who, with his brethren, holds a wordy war,
Loudly, he pleads and bawls, but trust ye me,
’Tis not for justice only,—but his fee.
The patriot, zealous for his country’s cause,
Warmly defends her liberty and laws;
But of his heart, too often, the intention
Is to grow popular, and gain a pension.

The formal student turns the sapient page,33 Cf. “sapient volume,” a phrase Turnbull uses recurrently; see “Elegy I,” line 20 and “The Vicissitudes of Fortune,” line 134, in Poetical Essays (1788) and “Epilogue” Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 1, 1796), line 11. Cf. also, "Enrag’d the rustic rout, with foul despight, / From Palinode the sapient volume tore,” from a Spenserian poem in praise of Spenser in “To the Editor: Remarks on the Opinion of Dr. Johnson concerning the Imitation of Spenser,” Edinburgh Magazine or Literary Miscellany, VI (August, 1787), p. 50.
Collecting wisdom from each ancient sage;
While careless mortals snore away the night,
He studies by the glimmering taper’s light;
Yet oft this weary toil—indeed ’tis true,
Is only for a benefice in view,
For wealth the merchant ventures on the main,
The learn’d physician practices for gain,
And, to be brief, without the least digression,
Gain is the end of every man’s profession:
For this the actor bellows on the stage,
Assumes the comic laugh or tragic rage,
And, Proteus44 Shape-shifter in book IV of Homer’s Odyssey. like, full many a shape he wears,
Now the gay youth, and then the man of years;
Now storms in 55 Richard III. Cf. Shakespeare, Richard III (1592?). with terrific frown,
And now a fop, anon a simple clown;
Next the starv-d valet, then the rednos’d host,
Sometimes an alderman, sometimes a ghost:
Yet all our labor in this strange vocation,
Is for your money and your approbation:
And happy I could my poor attempts the while,
From you extort one kind applausive smile.
To you whose patronage we share tonight,
What words can speak my heartfelt thanks aright,
T’ express my gratitude defies my skill,
Then kindly for the dead accept the will.
